tossups.question: Panna Bhatt gets offended by one of this man’s plays in “A Wife’s Story” by Bharati Mukherjee. This author wrote a play that opens with a man fantasizing about having sex with a woman who commits arson mid-coitus. A character created by this author shouts “I meet gestapo tactics!” after Baylen interrogates him. In a play by this author, a man says that he’ll go downtown to Mitch and Murray after James (*) Williamson ruins a deal between John Lingk and Ricky Roma. This author of Sexual Perversity in Chicago wrote a play that opens in a Chinese restaurant, where men discuss real estate leads. For 10 points, name this American playwright who wrote Glengarry Glen Ross.
tossups.answer: David (Alan) Mamet <RY, Drama>
tossups.answer_formatted: David Mamet <RY, Drama>

tossups.question: According to Pliny the Elder, one of these people invented the battleaxe. Diodorus Siculus wrote that these people dressed in snakeskin and made war with Atlantis at the orders of Myrina. After fighting the Solymoi and the Chimera, Bellerophon was ordered to attack these people. Thersites was killed for mocking the death of one of these people, who had been killed by a regretful (*) Achilles. After being kidnapped, a queen of these people gave birth to the firstborn son of Theseus. After Hera spread the rumor that one of these people was being kidnapped, Heracles was forced to kill her in order to retrieve her girdle. For 10 points, name this race of warrior women whose members included Penthesilea and Hippolyta.
tossups.answer: Amazons <VC, Myth>
tossups.answer_formatted: Amazons <VC, Myth>

tossups.question: This phenomenon is described by a zero-growth isocline [ICE-oh-klyne] occupied by vertical, not horizontal, lines. A 1989 paper described how scorpions engage in its “intraguild” type. In this phenomenon, C. S. Holling described three types of functional responses. Michael Rosenzweig described the paradox of enrichment, which is how this phenomenon is increased in response to an increase in carrying capacity. This phenomenon, which is absent in (*) refuges, is what initiates the oscillations in a Lotka–Volterra model. Aposematism [app-oh-SEM-at-ism] is the development of adaptations against this phenomenon, such as in Batesian mimicry. For 10 points, what phenomenon leads to the consumption of prey?
tossups.answer: predation [accept descriptions like “predators eating prey”] <RY, Biology>
tossups.answer_formatted: predation <RY, Biology> [accept descriptions like “predators eating prey]

tossups.question: When this city was requested to join the Holy League against France, it refused due to the influence of a preacher who was opposed by a faction called the “rabid” ones. After moving from Ferrara, an ecumenical council held in this city insisted on referring to Ethiopian Emperor Zara Yaqob as Prester John, much to the confusion of his delegation. After being ruled by a de facto theocracy, this city elected Piero Soderini as gonfaloniere for life in 1502. (*) Michele [mee-KEH-lay] di Lando led a rebellion of this city’s wool workers. Popes Clement VII and Leo X were members of this city’s most prominent family, two members of which were attacked while attending mass in the Duomo in 1478 in the Pazzi conspiracy. For 10 points, name this Tuscan city home to the Medici family.
tossups.answer: Florence [or Firenze] <AF, ContHist> [Note to moderator: please emphasize the underlined text]
tossups.answer_formatted: Florence <AF, ContHist> [Note to moderator: please emphasize the underlined text] [or Firenze]
acceptable: Florence <AF, ContHist> [Note to moderator: please emphasize the underlined text]
Florence <AF, ContHist> [Note to moderator: please emphasize the underlined text]

tossups.question: A short piece by this composer begins with the right hand playing the eighth notes [read slowly] “F A F C F high-F.” Several movements of a long piece by this composer include extensive hand-crossing, since they were meant to be played on two keyboards. That piece by this composer includes canons at every interval up to the ninth, as well as a (*) “Quodlibet.” This composer included several “little preludes” in a keyboard book for his eldest son, and included songs like “Bist du bei mir” in a Notebook for his second wife. He wrote two books of preludes and fugues in each major and minor key, as well as a piece recorded in 1955 by Glenn Gould. For 10 points, name this composer of the Goldberg Variations and The Well-Tempered Clavier.
tossups.answer: Johann Sebastian Bach [do not accept or prompt on any other Bachs] <JR, Music>
tossups.answer_formatted: Johann Sebastian Bach <JR, Music> [do not accept or prompt on "any other Bachs"]

tossups.question: Helen Caldwell identified one place’s “Othello” with a character from a novel in this language [emphasize] who acquires a moniker by saying “they are very fine” about verses read to him on the street. A novel in this language recounts how, to get a gift to Maximilian, the mahout [muh-HOWT] Subhro travels through the Alps with an elephant. Novelists using this language created the head of Ward Three, who demands sex slaves in exchange for food, and a character whose name means “Lord Taciturn.” The (*) Elephant’s Journey was written in this language, as was a novel in which a man who is stuck at a stoplight is the first to experience the title “white sickness,” which does not affect an unnamed ophthamologist’s wife. For 10 points, name this native language of the author of Blindness, José Saramago [zhoo-ZEH sah-rah-MAH-goo].
tossups.answer: Portuguese [or Português] (“Lord Taciturn” is Dom Casmurro) <WA, LongFic>
tossups.answer_formatted: Portuguese <WA, LongFic> [or Português]

tossups.question: A Twitter account named after this place made the surprisingly out-of-character tweet “SAD DAY FOR COUNTRY” in June 2016. Since 1885, this place has been illuminated by the Ayrton Light. The phrase “misery in the key of E” was used to describe a recent event at this place by Stephen Pound, who openly wept here. A popular Twitter account named for this place tweets some varying number of the word “BONG” every (*) hour. Leaders of the country where this landmark is located hope that, by March 29, 2019, this landmark will be functional once again in order to commemorate its country’s exit from the European Union. For 10 points, name this building currently undergoing renovation, a famous clock tower in London.
tossups.answer: Big Ben [or Elizabeth Tower; prompt on London] <VC, Other>
tossups.answer_formatted: Big Ben <VC, Other> [or Elizabeth Tower; prompt on London]

tossups.question: SDSS found that values of Petrosian R50 over R90 below 0.3 correspond to these objects. A feature of these non-solar system objects only occur between two Lindblad resonances. These objects comprise most of the blue cloud on color–magnitude diagrams. A “traffic jam” analogy is used to explain the density wave theory of Lin and Shu that describes these objects’ characteristic feature. Especially well-defined versions of these “late-type” objects are called (*) “Grand Design.” Luminosity of these objects is proportional to the third power of velocity according to the Tully–Fisher relation. These objects occupy the top rung of the Hubble tuning fork, with similar “barred” objects occupying the bottom rung. For 10 points, name these galaxies that, like the Milky Way, are not elliptical or irregular.
tossups.answer: spiral galaxies [prompt on partial answer; accept spiral galaxy after “galaxies” is read] <JL, Astro>
tossups.answer_formatted: spiral galaxies <JL, Astro> [prompt on partial answer; accept spiral galaxy after “galaxies” is read]

tossups.question: This document describes an institution that was once a thermostat for the mores of society, but has since become merely a thermometer and “archdefender of the status quo.” This document dismisses an objection by quoting T. S. Eliot’s line “The last temptation is the greatest treason: To do the right deed for the wrong reason.” This document was written in response to an open letter titled “A Call for Unity” and references Albert Boutwell’s recent electoral victory over “Bull” Connor. It paraphrases Earl Warren in stating that (*) “justice too long delayed is justice denied” and “Injustice anywhere is a threat to justice everywhere.” For 10 points, name this 1963 letter addressed to Southern church leaders, which was written by Martin Luther King, Jr., while he was incarcerated in Alabama.
tossups.answer: “Letter from a Birmingham Jail” [or “Letter from Birmingham Jail”] <RY, AmHist>
tossups.answer_formatted: “Letter from a Birmingham Jail” <RY, AmHist> [or Letter from Birmingham Jail]

tossups.question: Annette Weiner borrowed this thinker’s classifications of goods in the analysis employed in her book Inalienable Possessions, whose title concept originates with this thinker’s description of “pieces of property” as sacra. Claude Levi-Strauss’s introduction to this anthropologist’s work notes that he probably misunderstood the hau [how] system among the Māori. This anthropologist theorized that a “total social fact” may be constituted by a system of obligations of (*) reciprocity imbued within all parts of a society. His best-known work studies the potlatch practiced by the Kwakiutl and compares it with the kula ring to examine the effects of formalized exchange systems on society. For 10 points, name this nephew of Émile Durkheim and author of The Gift.
tossups.answer: Marcel Mauss <WA, SocSci>
tossups.answer_formatted: Marcel Mauss <WA, SocSci>

tossups.question: This author’s words “Such sweet compulsion doth in music lie” are spoken by the Genius of the Wood in the poem Arcades. This poet wrote “Come, and trip it as you go / On the light fantastic toe,” leading to the modern-day idiom “trip the light fantastic” in a poem that states “These delights if thou canst give / Mirth, with thee I mean to live.” This poet wrote a pair of poems opening “Hence, loathed Melancholy” and “Hence, vain deluding Joys” that contrast a (*) happy man and a serious one. Thomas Gray’s “Elegy Written in a Country Churchyard” imagines “some mute inglorious” version of this poet. For 10 points, L’allegro and Il penseroso are poems by what English writer of Paradise Lost?
tossups.answer: John Milton <RY, Poetry>
tossups.answer_formatted: John Milton <RY, Poetry>

tossups.question: The spatial derivative of the voltage equals the strength of one of these circuit elements times the time derivative of the current according to the first telegrapher’s equation. Chokes, a type of low pass filter, are usually made of these elements. When two of these circuit elements are coupled, they form a transformer. Frequency times i times the strength of these devices equals their (*) impedance [im-PEE-dense]. These devices are represented on circuit diagrams by a coiled line, since a wire wrapped around a conducting core is a simple way to make one of them. These devices are the “L” in an LRC circuit. For 10 points, name these circuit elements, whose namesake property is measured in henrys, which are best exemplified by solenoids.
tossups.answer: inductors [accept word forms like inductance; anti-prompt on specific varieties of inductors until they are read, such as solenoid] <JL, Phys>
tossups.answer_formatted: inductors <JL, Phys> [accept word forms like inductance; anti-prompt on specific varieties of inductors until they are read, such as solenoid]

tossups.question: In this modern-day country, numerous clay tablets and the palace of king Zimri-Lim were found at the ancient site of Mari. This country’s Kurkh Monolith, recounting the Battle of Qarqar, attests to the existence of a historical King Ahab. An ancient Greek name for this region called it “hollow,” or “Coele” [koh-EH-leh]. The Roman province with this name was merged with one to the [emphasize] south after the Bar Kokhba revolt. Queen Zenobia founded a breakaway state of the Roman Empire in this country’s city of (*) Palmyra. This country’s present-day capital was famous for producing intricately-patterned steel, and was the seat of power of the Umayyad caliphs. For 10 points, name this modern-day country home to Aleppo and Damascus.
tossups.answer: Syria [do not accept or prompt on “Assyria”] <RY, Ancient>
tossups.answer_formatted: Syria <RY, Ancient> [do not accept or prompt on "Assyria"]

tossups.question: A plan to have the firm Olson Kundig renovate this building by adding glass balustrades was announced in 2017 and called the “Century Project.” This building is the tallest and most iconic example of “Googie” architecture. John Minasian was a structural engineer for this building, whose design originated with Eddie Carlson’s sketch on a napkin, and includes an olive-colored body and a gold roof. This building is located right next to the (*) Museum of Pop Culture designed by Frank Gehry, formerly known as the Experience Music Project, as well as the monorail built for the same event as this building. Its elevators were used by nearly 20,000 people per day during the 1962 World’s Fair, for which it was built. For 10 points, what extraterrestrial-looking tower is found in Seattle?
tossups.answer: Seattle Space Needle <WA, OVisArt>
tossups.answer_formatted: Seattle Space Needle <WA, OVisArt>

tossups.question: A “great” book of hours produced in this empire prescribes ending the day with a typica when liturgy is not performed. A set of religious rules [emphasize] named for this empire require that incense be distributed at the beginning of all-night vigils; those rules require forgoing dairy and eggs, [emphasize] as well as meat, during the four great fasts. In an incident in this empire, a scholar named Barlaam accused others of heresy for defending the mystical practice of (*) hesychasm [HEZ-ih-KAZ-um]. The Christian “rite” named for this empire includes the feast of the Dormition and is used in the churches of Antioch, Georgia, Serbia, and Russia. For 10 points, name this empire whose rulers lost the ability to appoint patriarchs in 1453 when Constantinople fell.
tossups.answer: Byzantine Empire [accept Eastern Roman empire; accept Byzantine rite; prompt on Greek empire; prompt on Roman empire for historical purposes, but it’s almost always called “Greek Rite” or “Byzantine Rite”] <WA, Rel>
tossups.answer_formatted: Byzantine Empire <WA, Rel> [accept Eastern Roman empire; accept Byzantine rite; prompt on Greek empire; prompt on Roman empire for historical purposes, but it’s almost always called “Greek Rite or Byzantine Rite]
promptable: Roman empire for historical purposes, but it’s almost always called “Greek Rite

tossups.question: The book Experience and Judgment explains a type of this method that uses “free variation” of the imagination to understand the essence of the world; that “eidetic” method is used in the phenomenology of Edmund Husserl. A core argument for intelligent design developed by Michael Behe is that biological systems cannot be subjected to this method. To refer to a particular fallacy of irrelevance, Leo Strauss coined a term involving this method and (*) Hitler. The “ontological” form of this method is exemplified by René Descartes explaining non-human animals as automata. For 10 points, give this philosophical term that generally refers to boiling something down to simpler parts, or to taking an opponent’s conclusions “to the absurd.”
tossups.answer: reduction [or word forms such as reductionism; or reductio (ad absurdum, etc.); accept eidetic reduction; accept irreducible complexity; accept epoché until “eidetic”] <WA, PhilO>
tossups.answer_formatted: reduction <WA, PhilO> [or word forms such as reductionism; or reductio (ad absurdum, etc.); accept eidetic reduction; accept irreducible complexity; accept epoché until “eidetic]

tossups.question: A peasant uprising in this country was led by a man whom the Regalado family hung by his thumbs; that man, Feliciano Ama, organized the Pipil people. A war that this country fought with its eastern neighbor led to a suspension of a regional common market until the creation of SICA in 1991. The El Mozote massacre was a part of the “draining the sea” scorched earth tactics that this country’s army used in a civil war against the FMLN, a party named for peasant leader (*) Farabundo Marti. Roberto D’Aubuisson [DAHB-wee-sawn], founder of the ARENA party in this country, is believed to have ordered the assassination of Óscar Romero. For 10 points, identify this Central American country that fought Honduras in the Soccer War, whose name means “the Savior.”
tossups.answer: El Salvador <AF, WorldHist>
tossups.answer_formatted: El Salvador <AF, WorldHist>

tossups.question: In a named reaction of this type, hydroxylamine, sodium methoxide, and acetic anhydride are sequentially reacted with glucose to convert it to arabinose. The aldol condensation proceeds via this reaction type after a carbonyl group is deprotonated to an enol [EEN-all], its conjugate base. Bulky substituents like tert-butyl can lock cyclohexane into a conformation that maximizes rates of reactions of this type due to maximal s-orbital overlap, called (*) antiperiplanar. Potassium-t-butoxide reacting with tertiary carbons would enable these reactions to proceed faster than competing ones since it maximizes steric hindrance. Hydrogen is removed from the carbon with the least hydrogens according to Zaitsev’s rule for these reactions. For 10 points, name these reactions, contrasted with substitution reactions, where two substituents are removed from a hydrocarbon to form an alkene.
tossups.answer: elimination reaction [accept any specific subtypes, such as Wohl degradation, dehydration, E1, E2, E1cb, unimolecular elimination, etc.; prompt on E] <JL, Chem>
tossups.answer_formatted: elimination reaction <JL, Chem> [accept any specific subtypes, such as Wohl degradation, dehydration, E1, E2, E1cb, unimolecular elimination, etc.; prompt on E]
acceptable: any specific subtypes, such as Wohl degradation, dehydration, E1, E2, E1cb, unimolecular elimination, etc.

tossups.question: A significant number of artworks from this non-French country were destroyed in the 2004 Momart fire destroyed. Yuan Chai and Jian Jun Xi [jyen jwin shee] jumped around on an artwork from this country before having a 15-minute pillow fight on top of it; the same artist from here created a tent with the names of “Everyone I Have Ever Slept With: 1963–1995.” Tracey Emin works in this country. Former ad mogul (*) Charles Saatchi collects works primarily made by artists from here. An artist from this country sparked the Stuckist movement in his work The Physical Impossibility of Death in the Mind of Someone Living, which shows a tiger shark preserved in a vat of formaldehyde. For 10 points, name this home of Damien Hirst, whose namesake “Young Artists” sometimes exhibit at the Tate Modern.
tossups.answer: the United Kingdom [accept Great Britain, the UK, GB; accept England as well, since all the artists talked about are specifically English] <EX, Painting>
tossups.answer_formatted: the United Kingdom <EX, Painting> [accept Great Britain, the UK, GB; accept England as well, since all the artists talked about are specifically English]

tossups.question: In a story by this author, Ralph locks himself in the bathroom after he finds out about his wife Marian’s infidelity. Nathan Englander borrowed the title of a short story by this author for his own collection of short stories titled after Anne Frank. A group of friends discuss how Ed failed to kill himself by ingesting rat poison in one of this author’s stories, in which the narrator describes how he could (*) “hear his heart beating” and the “human noise” he and his friends were making. This author of “Will You Please be Quiet, Please?” wrote about Mel, Terri, Nick and Laura discussing the title emotion at a dinner party in his most famous story. For 10 points, name this author of What We Talk About When We Talk About Love.
tossups.answer: Raymond (Clevie) Carver <SB, Short> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses
tossups.answer_formatted: Raymond Carver <SB, Short> IF THE GAME IS TIED AT THIS POINT, READ A QUESTION FROM THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. THEN, FOLLOW THE INSTRUCTIONS IN THE TIEBREAKER PACKET. Bonuses

bonuses.leadin: Because it is encoded by a housekeeping gene, the enzyme GAPDH [gap-D-H] is used as a loading control for this procedure. For 10 points each:
parts: What common laboratory biology technique separates proteins with gel electrophoresis, transfers the protein to a membrane, and uses antibodies to label proteins of interest?

The beta isoform of this protein is another common loading control, since it is a fundamental component of microfilaments in the cytoskeleton. Muscle contracts because of this protein’s binding with myosin.

Housekeeping genes like GAPDH have this kind of expression, meaning they are produced in the cell at all times. For example, the lac operon experiences this kind of expression if the lac repressor gene is mutated.

bonuses.leadin: After his execution, a pouch of this good was found in the cell of Sir Walter Raleigh with a Latin inscription saying that “It was my companion at that most miserable time.” For 10 points each:
answers: James I [or James VI of Scotland; prompt on James]
parts: Name this good that Raleigh helped popularize in England. John Rolfe was the first person to grow this crop commercially at Jamestown.

This man expressed his dislike of tobacco in A Counterblaste to Tobacco. This man adopted a rose dimidiated [dim-MID-ee-ated] with a Scottish thistle as his personal badge to represent his simultaneous holding of two posts.

Tobacco was often traded in a pattern resembling this shape, flowing from Virginia to the Caribbean, then to the Britain. Rum, molasses, and sugar were all key components in an Atlantic trade pattern that took this shape.
answers_formatted: James I [or James VI of Scotland; prompt on James]

bonuses.leadin: A bluesy one of these pieces was written for organ, and another one of these pieces was nicknamed “Short” because it was only 15 minutes long. For 10 points each:
answers: Aaron Copland (the symphonies in the first part are all by Aaron Copland)
film scores [accept any answers indicating that they were written for movies] <EX, Music>
parts: Name this musical genre. The third and last of these works by an American composer reuses a fanfare theme adapted from an earlier, World War II-inspired work commissioned by Eugene Goossens.
This composer’s Symphony No. 3, as well as Fanfare for the Common Man, are written in his typical “Americana” style. He also composed the ballets Appalachian Spring and Billy the Kid.
Copland composed several works in this genre of music based on John Steinbeck novels. Bernard Herrmann was a prominent 20th-century composer in this genre of music, which is generally non-diegetic.
answers_formatted: film scores <EX, Music> [accept any answers indicating that they were written for movies]
acceptable: any answers indicating that they were written for movies
metadata: the symphonies in the first part are all by Aaron Copland

bonuses.leadin: In a story found in both the Jataka tales and Aesop’s fables, a donkey wears one of these objects in order to frighten other animals. For 10 points each:
answers: lion’s skin [accept equivalents for “skin” such as hide; prompt on skin or hide]
parts: Identify this kind of object. In a tale involving Heracles, this sort of object is impenetrable, so a man must defeat its possessor by strangulation, then remove it using that dead possessor’s claws.

The Indian story “The Lion and the Woodpecker” is analogous to an Aesop fable about one of these animals and a crane. In another Aesop fable, a boy falsely claims that one of these animals attacks his flock of sheep.
In other Indian tales related to lions, Vishnu manifests as this half-lion, half-man avatar in order to protect his devoted follower Prahlada from Hiranyakashipu.
answers_formatted: lion’s skin [accept equivalents for “skin” such as hide; prompt on skin or hide]

bonuses.leadin: A propagandized re-envisioned history of this battle inserted Napoleon into it, even though Napoleon did not take part in this battle at all. For 10 points each:
answers: Battle of the Cowshed [accept equivalents with that specific underlined word; definitely DO NOT accept “Battle of Cowpens”]
the windmill [accept anything involving a windmill] <WA, LongFic>
parts: Name this battle at which a “stable-lad from Oxwood” was killed by a large rearing stallion. In this battle, strategically positioned livestock were used to cut off retreat by farmers.
This author used the Battle of the Cowshed as an allegory of the Russian Civil War in his novel Animal Farm.
The actual hero of the Battle of the Cowshed, Snowball, meets his downfall when he is attacked by propaganda claiming that he tried to sabotage the creation of this building.
answers_formatted: Battle of the Cowshed [accept equivalents with that specific underlined word; definitely DO NOT accept “Battle of Cowpens”]
acceptable: equivalents with that specific underlined word

bonuses.leadin: In this film, a dollying camera follows three men whose footsteps echo in a puddle-filled tunnel, nicknamed the “Meat-Grinder,” from which they enter a room filled with dunes. For 10 points each:
answers: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; prompt on Russia]
parts: Name this film based on the novel Roadside Picnic. It follows three men who seek a wish-granting room in a dangerous area called “the Zone.”
The director of Stalker, Andrei Tarkovsky, was from this country, and the film was produced by its Mosfilm studio. Mosfilm also produced this country’s film Battleship Potemkin.

This director created a film about the Siberian hunter Dersu Uzala for Mosfilm. A Fistful of Dollars is a remake of this non-Russian director’s film about two criminal families competing for the services of a bodyguard.
answers_formatted: Soviet Union [or USSR; or Union of Soviet Socialist Republics; prompt on Russia]

bonuses.leadin: SO(3) [S-O-three] is the group of all types of this kind of motion in three dimensions. For 10 points each:
answers: rotation [accept word forms; accept equivalents like spinning]
parts: Name this type of motion in which an object moves at a constant separation from a fixed center. A top undergoes this motion in its normal movement and also while it precesses.

When Euler angles are used to describe the orientation and rotation of a rigid body in space, this phenomenon can cause the system to lose a degree of freedom when two of the namesake supports have parallel axes.
In aeronautics, the Euler angles are given three names: pitch, yaw, and this third angle. It describes rotation around the axis that points from the nose of the plane through its tail.

bonuses.leadin: This poet wrote about the horror of seeing women’s breasts “in the National Geographic” while in the waiting room of a dentist’s office with Aunt Consuelo. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this poet who worked for 20 years on a poem about an animal that darts in front of a bus and leaves a “dim smell” in the woods titled “The Moose.”
Bishop used this 19-line poetic form in her work “One Art,” which states “the art of losing isn’t hard to master.”
Bishop set many of her poems like “In The Waiting Room” in this home state where she grew up in Worcester. Emily Dickinson was born in its city of Amherst.

bonuses.leadin: This term is applied to Leo Tolstoy’s theory of history, which argues that a leader’s greatness is heavily determined by their historical milieu, as opposed to Carlyle’s “Great Man” theory. For 10 points each:
answers: Elements of the Philosophy of Right [or Grundlinien der Philosophie des Rechts] <WA, PhilO>
parts: Give this term of German origin, used to refer to the animating “spirit” of a particular epoch in human history.
The word Zeitgeist was never actually used by this German idealist, though similar ideas are reflected in his magnum opus, The Phenomenology of Spirit.

Hegel explained the role of the spirit of the times in the development of the state to higher stages in this work, which posits the idea of “ethical life,” in which individual and universal morality are unified.
answers_formatted: Elements of the Philosophy of Right <WA, PhilO> [or Grundlinien der Philosophie des Rechts]
acceptable: Elements of the Philosophy of Right <WA, PhilO>
Elements of the Philosophy of Right <WA, PhilO>

bonuses.leadin: Adam Czerniakow [CHAIRN-yah-kov] took a cyanide pill when this district’s population was deported to Treblinka as part of a Grossaktion in 1942. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this district within a European city, where an uprising was crushed by troops under Jurgen Stroop.
The Warsaw Ghetto Uprising was crushed by troops of the armed, Waffen division of this group. Heinrich Himmler was the leader of this Nazi paramilitary organization.

The Nazis controlled the ghetto in this third-largest Polish city through Chaim Rumkowski [KHA-eem room-KOFF-skee], a Jewish leader who is remembered for giving a speech exclaiming “Fathers and mothers: Give me your children!”

bonuses.leadin: The Western Federation of Miners was called the “mining section” of this organization until splitting off from this organization, leading to riots in Butte [byoot], Montana. For 10 points each:
answers: IWW [or Industrial Workers of the World]
parts: Name this large union. Members of this group sometimes went by the nickname “Wobblies.”
The IWW’s policy was to have an “open union” in order to achieve a “closed” one of these things. A workplace that mandates union membership is called a “closed” [this term].
The IWW’s collectivist motto claimed that this sort of thing “to one” is the same as this sort of thing “to all.”

bonuses.leadin: In September 2017, Aung San Suu Kyi [ong sahn soo chee] referred to news about this ethnic group as “a huge iceberg of misinformation.” For 10 points each:
parts: Name this Muslim ethnic group whose members have undergone a mass exodus from Rakhine [ruh-KYNE] state. Myanmar’s military launched a campaign against these people in response to an attack by the Arakan Salvation Army.
Hundreds of thousands of Rohingya refugees went to this Muslim-majority neighbor of Myanmar. It gained its independence from Pakistan in 1971.
This leader of Bangladesh refused Rohingya refugees in 2012. This current prime minister of Bangladesh leads the Awami League and is a rival of Khaleda Zia, who leads the Bangladesh National Party.

bonuses.leadin: According to the Anfinsen Dogma, the free energy surface of protein folding must resemble this type of structure. For 10 points each:
answers: liquid–liquid extraction [or LLE; or solvent extraction and partitioning]
parts: Name this structure, a variant of which was developed for filtration purposes in conjunction with a vacuum flask by Büchner [BYOOK-ner].
A separatory funnel is used in this procedure that transfers a chemical product between two different types of solvent, usually one that is organic and water.
The organic and aqueous solvents in liquid–liquid extraction are referred to by this term, which also refers to states of matter and the transitions between them like boiling and melting.

bonuses.leadin: Guru Gobind Singh founded this group, and required them to do things such as avoiding alcohol and haircuts. For 10 points each:
answers: Amrit Sanchar [or Khande di Pahul; prompt on partial answer]
Guru Granth Sahib [or Adi Granth] <VC, Rel>
parts: Give this term that refers to the community of all observant Sikhs, whose members observe the Five Ks.

People are admitted to the khalsa after undergoing this ceremony in which they are purified with water. Guru Gobind Singh invited people to the first one of these ceremonies where he pretended to behead the participants.
The Mul Mantar begins this holy text of Sikhism. After the death of Guru Gobind Singh, this book became accepted as the eternal leader of the Sikh community.
answers_formatted: Amrit Sanchar [or Khande di Pahul; prompt on partial answer]

bonuses.leadin: The first essay in this series defines “three senses” of its title concept on the levels of the individual, the group, and the whole society. For 10 points each:
answers: Notes Toward a Definition of Culture [or Notes Toward the Definition of Culture]
Dante Alighieri [accept either underlined portion] <WA, OtherLit>
parts: Name this series of social criticism essays by T. S. Eliot, which presents the title concept as “the one thing that we cannot deliberately aim at.” It includes discussions of “Derby Day” and the “Henley Regatta.”

Eliot’s work criticizes the definition of culture as “the best which has been thought and said” that this author put forth in Culture and Anarchy. This poet wrote the line “Ah, love, let us be true to one another!”
Paul Douglass argues that Eliot’s models were Arnold and this author, in whom Arnold identified the “accent of high seriousness.” Eliot’s “Prufrock” has an epigraph from this man’s The Divine Comedy.
answers_formatted: Notes Toward a Definition of Culture [or Notes Toward the Definition of Culture]
acceptable: Notes Toward a Definition of Culture
Notes Toward a Definition of Culture
Notes Toward the Definition of Culture

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about famous art thefts, for 10 points each.
parts: A 1967 theft at the University of Michigan stole several works by Henry Moore and this other artist, though they were later recovered at a California auction house. His works include Les Demoiselles d’Avignon.

Works formerly hung in this city such as The Concert by Vermeer and Chez Tortoni by Manet were stolen in a 13-work heist from an art museum in this city in 1990. That theft, valued at over 500 million dollars, is the largest private property theft in history.
The Musée Marmottan had this painting stolen in 1985 before it was found in Corsica six years later. Louis Leroy [le-RWAH] gave this painting its fame in a review of an 1874 exhibition.

bonuses.leadin: A stage manager, dramatic poet, and a comedic actor debate whether one should create art for the sake of the public while discussing possible reactions to this play. For 10 points each:
parts: Name this play discussed by three men in a theater before the director urges everyone to get back to work on presenting audiences the “circle of Creation.”

The “Prelude in the Theatre” begins Faust and is followed by a “Prologue in [this location]” where a bet is made between Mephisto and God over whether Faust will still “know the path which is true and fit” after being tempted to sin.
Faust was written by this German poet who also wrote The Sorrows of Young Werther.

bonuses.leadin: Answer some questions about social psychology studies that just refuse to be replicated, for 10 points each.
answers: poses [or postures; prompt on related terms like body language]
parts: Amy Cuddy made waves in 2012 with a TED Talk concerning the “power” form of these things, which Eva Ranehill failed to replicate with a double blind set-up. These nonverbal behaviors can usually be seen during job interviews with insecure people.

John Ioadannis [yo-ah-DAH-nis] published a 2005 article about why most published research is false during his tenure at this university. It was home to a notable “prison experiment” led by Philip Zimbardo.

Roy Baumeister’s research on this concept failed to replicate in recent research using over 2,000 participants. This concept refers to the idea that self-control draws upon a pool of limited mental resources that can be used up.
answers_formatted: poses [or postures; prompt on related terms like body language]

bonuses.leadin: In a model represented as y equals a x plus b, where y represents the outcome, x would be the variable of this type. For 10 points each:
answers: binary [accept descriptive answers like “having only two values” or “being one or zero” or “being true or false”]
parts: Give the term for these variables, which are altered by the designers of studies or experiments in order to study whether a change results.
In statistical modeling, “dummy” variables, which are used to refer to categories such as race and education level, have this property, like the variables in Boolean algebra.

Seasonal dummy variables may be used to account for changes during the year when performing analysis on this kind of panel data. A list of daily closing values of a stock exchange is an example of data in this form.
answers_formatted: binary [accept descriptive answers like “having only two values or being one or zero or being true or false]
acceptable: descriptive answers like “having only two values

bonuses.leadin: Answer the following about aristocratic women in Heian [HAY-on] Japan, for 10 points each.
answers: The Tale of Genji [or Genji monogatari] <AF, WorldHist>
parts: Calligraphy was an essential part of any high-born woman’s education, particularly in the newly-developing kana syllabary. However, only men typically wrote in this Chinese-derived logographic system still in use today.
This clan gained much power in the Heian period by marrying its daughters into the imperial family. Michinaga of this clan was the father-in-law of four emperors and grandfather to three.
This work, often called the world’s first novel, is an important insight into Heian court life. It features the blank chapter “Vanished into the Clouds” and was written by Lady Murasaki Shikibu.
